metadata.Title: CVE-2017-1000083 on Ubuntu 16.04 ESM (xenial) - medium.
metadata.Description:
backend/comics/comics-document.c (aka the comic book backend) in GNOME Evince before 3.24.1 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands via a .cbt file that is a TAR archive containing a filename beginning with a "--" command-line option substring, as demonstrated by a --checkpoint-action=exec=bash at the beginning of the filename. Felix Wilhelm discovered that Evince did not safely invoke tar when handling tar comic book (cbt) files. An attacker could use this to construct a malicious comic book format file that, when opened in Evince, executes arbitrary code.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2017-1000083` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

atril - 1.12.2-1ubuntu0.2
atril-common - 1.12.2-1ubuntu0.2
gir1.2-atril - 1.12.2-1ubuntu0.2
libatrildocument3 - 1.12.2-1ubuntu0.2
libatrilview3 - 1.12.2-1ubuntu0.2
No subscription required

evince - 3.18.2-1ubuntu4.1
evince-common - 3.18.2-1ubuntu4.1
evince-gtk - 3.18.2-1ubuntu4.1
gir1.2-evince-3.0 - 3.18.2-1ubuntu4.1
libevdocument3-4 - 3.18.2-1ubuntu4.1
libevview3-3 - 3.18.2-1ubuntu4.1
Available with Ubuntu Pro (Infra-only): https://ubuntu.com/pro

notes.Note: sbeattie> upstream evince in git has switched to using libarchive The fix for this issue disables CBT support, as tar offers to many opportunities to invoke commands and CBT is a rarely used comic book format.

criterions.comment: atril package in xenial was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '1.12.2-1ubuntu0.2').
evince package in xenial was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '3.18.2-1ubuntu4.1').
